attributes.title: Dissonance vicariante dans un contexte Français : réagir à l’inconsistance des autres
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Presence of error in this preregistration
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

q2.value: Michelle Lancee, Marleen Schuring, Joeri K. Tijdink, Christiaan Vinkers, Jurjen J Luykx

q3.value:
In 2000 the National Institutes of Health (NIH) created a registry and results database: ClinicalTrials.gov. The FDA Amendments Act of 2007 mandated the registration and submission of clinical trials to Clinicaltrials.gov. The aim of this pre-registration of studies was to minimize outcome reporting bias, defined as selective publishing of clinical trial outcomes.
Nonetheless, outcome reporting bias remains widespread. Such bias may affect the weight attributed to the results of these trials. In the field of psychiatry, outcome reporting bias was demonstrated recently for antipsychotics and a couple of years ago for antidepressants in subjects suffering from anxiety disorders.
To gain insight in the extent of outcome reporting in psychiatry, we will systematically investigate outcome reporting bias in trials of frequently applied FDA-approved treatments for schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorders, depression and bipolar disorder.

q4.value:
1.	Which factors are associated with outcome reporting bias (ORB) in randomized controlled trials investigating treatments for major depressive disorder (MDD), bipolar disorder and schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder?

2.	Is outcome reporting bias associated with the directionality of efficacy outcomes (positive or negative compared to the H.0 hypothesis)?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data was obtained by four different research authors and randomly checked by one research author (ML). No analyses were performed prior to creating the research protocol.

question.value:
A search was performed on ClinicalTrials.gov using key words "schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder and antipsychotics", "antidepressant or mood stabilizer and depressive disorder or bipolar disorder" with study dates ranging from 1 January 2006 to 1 January 2015. 
Inclusion criteria: phase II, III, IV studies, randomized, closed studies, FDA approved medication for diagnosis of depression/MDD/schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder/bipolar disorder
Exclusion criteria: no matching publication, other disease as primary outcome, non FDA approved medication for specific diagnosis
Matching publications were searched on PubMed and Embase.
Baseline characteristics were recorderd as well as the primary and secondary outcomes from both study protocol and corresponding study publication. Outcomes from both the study protocol and study publication were compared and defined as added, changed, deleted or unchanged.

q13.value: All available RCTs meeting the predefined in- and exclusion criteria will be included in all analyses.

q14.value: Based on our previous study (Lancee et al, Translational Psychiatry, 2017) we estimate we will need a minimum of 48 RCTs.

q15.value: Search will be done on a specific date.

question.value:
1.	The funding source, included as a categorical value (NIH, Industry, Other)
2.	Disorder, included as a categorical value (major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia)
3.	Year of study start as a numerical value, ranging from 2006-2015
4.	Number of participating centers as a dichotomous value (mono- or multi center)
5.	Anticipated sample size as a numerical value

All research question 1-related hypotheses will be tested within the same analysis. We will perform a multivariable logistic regression with the main determinants and the outcome measure ‘presence of outcome reporting bias ’. 
For research question 2, one-sided Fisher exact test will be used to compare the proportions of newly added positive outcomes with the proportions of positive results in the group of non-altered research outcomes.
The significance threshold will be set at 0.05.

q21.value: The significance threshold will be set at 0.05.

q23.value: studies with missing data for a specific outcome will be included for the other outcomes. missing data will not be imputed.

attributes.title: LAM country survey
attributes.description: We are trying to understand country policy adoption and uptake/implementation of urine LF-LAM testing for TB. To this end, we administered a semi-structured survey to 31 high TB/HIV burden countries

summary.value: We conducted a survey to understand country's policy adoption and real-world implementation of a lateral flow urine LAM test for TB. In this registration are a copy of the survey we sent out as well as all the survey responses we received.

registration_responses.summary: We conducted a survey to understand country's policy adoption and real-world implementation of a lateral flow urine LAM test for TB. In this registration are a copy of the survey we sent out as well as all the survey responses we received.

attributes.title: The Effect of Rewarding Inhibition on SSRT and Trigger Failure Rate using a Block-level Reward Manipulation

q1.value: The Effect of Rewarding Inhibition on SSRT and Trigger Failure Rate using a Block-level Reward Manipulation

q2.value: Roos Doekemeijer, C. Nico Boehler, Frederick Verbruggen

q3.value:
In accordance with Logan and Cowan’s (1984) horse race model, it is widely believed that the success of inhibiting an ongoing response depends on (1) the latency of the ongoing go process (measured as ‘go RT’), (2) the latency of the stop process (‘SSRT’), and the delay between the onsets of these two processes (‘SSD’). As the SSRT cannot be observed directly, it is typically estimated from the information at hand, e.g., by using the integration approach or Bayesian parameter estimation. Using such methods, researchers have been able to examine within- and between-individual differences in SSRT. As a specific example, research has found that rewarding correctly inhibited responses reduces SSRTs (e.g., Boehler, Hopf, Stoppel, & Krebs, 2012).	
 	Peculiarly, the vast majority of said research has operated under the assumption that the stop process occurs without fail, although the concept of ‘trigger failures’ (i.e., failures to start the stop process) has been around for over 25 years. It has been proposed that some differences attributed to differences in SSRT might actually reflect differences in the rates of trigger failures instead (Logan, 1994). To address this major concern, a recent method (BEESTS-WTF; Matzke, Love, & Heathcote, 2017) was developed that accounts for the possibility of trigger failure (P_TF) when estimating SSRTs. 
 	So far, we have employed BEESTS-WTF to reanalyze data from four of our previous studies (Boehler et al., 2012 (two separate behavioral studies); Schevernels, Krebs, Bombeke, & Boehler, 2015; Boehler, Schevernels, Hopf, Stoppel, & Krebs, 2014). In all four studies, we had used a stimulus-reward association set-up (in which the stop stimulus in a stop-signal task could be presented in one of two colors, one color was associated with reward, the other wasn’t) and obtained SSRTs via traditional non-parametric SSRT estimation (i.e., integration approach). From the initial analyses, we had concluded that rewarding inhibition led to shorter SSRTs. Yet, from the re-analyses of the data using BEESTS-WTF, we concluded that the effect of reward was driven by a decrease in trigger failure rather than by a decrease in SSRTs. Overall, there appears to be a convergence across these earlier studies that most of the difference in rewarded and non-rewarded behavior is not in the core SSRT —as has been believed previously— but in a differential rate of trigger failures. 
 	Nevertheless, these findings are limited due to the properties of the re-examined studies. Firstly, all four studies had relatively small sample sizes (ranging from 16 to 19 participants). Secondly, the general context between the studies differed considerably (i.e., the data sets originated from two behavioral studies, an EEG study, and an fMRI study), so the data sets could not be considered parts of single data set. Finally, and most importantly, all studies had used a stimulus-reward association set-up, with two different types of stop stimuli randomly intermixed within blocks. This was used to avoid any SSRT estimation problems caused by behavioral differences in the go trials. However, this particularity of the experiment could have triggered some mechanistic implementation of the reward effect (e.g., feature-based attention that enabled the superior processing of one color over that of the other) that is unlikely to play a role in other response inhibition set-ups, which ultimately confines the generalizability of our findings.
 	In the present study, we therefore aim to replicate our previous findings on the effect of reward on SSRTs and trigger failure rate in a more typical response inhibition set-up, i.e., we plan to manipulate reward across separate task blocks, use stop stimuli that are identical across reward manipulation, and simply signal reward availability by instruction. Overall, we intend to set up and employ an online, within-subjects experiment in full accordance to a recent consensus paper (Verbruggen et al., 2019), to analyze the acquired data using the integration approach, BEESTS without accounting for trigger failures (‘standard BEESTS’; Matzke, Dolan, Logan, Brown, & Wagenmakers, 2013), and BEESTS-WTF.

q4.value: Based on our findings obtained from the re-analyses of existing data sets, we expect that rewarding successful inhibition (1) decreases SSRTs according to the integration approach and standard BEESTS, (2) does not affect SSRTs, but rather reduces the rate of trigger failures according to BEESTS-WTF, compared to not rewarding successful inhibition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: We will not get into (direct) contact with the participants, as the experiment is intended to be conducted online via Prolific.co.

question.value:
We will employ a within-subjects block design with one factor, namely reward (‘reward’ blocks vs. ‘no reward’ blocks). We intend to employ five blocks of each type and will alternate them within individuals. Whether participants start with a ‘no reward’ block or a reward block will be counterbalanced.

Before the start of the experimental blocks, participants will be asked for their consent, their Prolific ID, their age and their gender. Next, participants will receive a practice block, consisting of three parts. In the first part, participants will be instructed to respond to the go stimuli (a green arrow pointing left or a green arrow pointing right) using the appropriate response keys (pressing the left arrow key to the left-pointing arrow or the right arrow key to the right-pointing arrow); 12 balanced go trials follow in random order, in which the participants will receive immediate feedback. 	
 	In the second part, participants will be instructed to stop their response in the presence of an added stop stimulus (a red box surrounding the go stimulus) presented after a variable delay and are warned that they should try to perform appropriately in both tasks without strategically slowing down their responses to the go stimuli; 40 randomized practice trials, of which 10 stop trials (balanced over go stimuli); again receiving immediate feedback.
 	In the final part, the participants will be informed that (1) in some of the upcoming blocks they can earn 10 points for successfully inhibiting their response, while not in others; (2) they will be informed about the block type at the start of each block and that symbols (‘#’ in the no reward blocks; ‘£’ in the reward blocks) will be put in a diamond shape on their screen around the area of the task-relevant stimuli as a reminder of the block type; (3) their final score will amount to a monetary bonus after the experiment, given that they performed adequately on the both the go and stop task; (4) for every 10 points, they will earn £0.05, to a maximum of 600 points (amounting to £3; explained using a table); (5) they cannot pause the experiment (lasting about 35 more minutes) beyond short fixed-duration breaks once they decide to continue.

Within each of the 10 experimental blocks, each participant is to perform 96 trials of the visual-visual Stop-Signal Task (SST), totaling to 960 trials. Each of these 960 trials starts with a 250 ms fixation point, followed by a go stimulus for 600 ms, then a blank screen for some variable duration (between 750 and 950 ms, steps of 1/60 seconds using a boxcar distribution). Note that these desired delays might differ slightly from the actual delays due to the browser’s refresh rate; to get the closest to our desired delays, we will therefore throttle the refresh rate of each participant to 60 Hz.
 	In the 72 go trials (i.e., representing 75% of the trials), the participant is to respond to the go stimulus as fast and accurately as possible, at the very latest before the start of the new trial. So, in our experiment, the participants will be able to respond during stimulus presentation but also still during the blank screen. Nevertheless, we will strongly encourage them to respond fast. 
 	In the 24 stop trials (25% of trials), a red box will appear around the go stimulus after a delay (i.e., the stop-signal delay, SSD), indicating to the participant that they should inhibit their response. If the participant is successful in inhibiting their response, they will earn 10 points in a ‘reward’ block and no points in a ‘no reward’ block, which will be converted to a monetary bonus at the end of the experiment (£0.05 for every 10 points to a maximum of 600 points, £3). Moreover, the SSD will be updated dynamically based on the participant’s success on these stop trials: if the participant is successful in inhibiting their response, the SSD will be decreased by 50 ms (to a minimum of 50 ms); if not, the SSD will be increased by 50 ms (to a maximum of 550 ms). We will employ two independent staircases, one of for each block type, and will employ an additional staircase for the practice block. The starting value of this SSD staircase in the practice block will be set to 200 ms for each participant, then the starting values of experimental staircases will be set to the final SSD of the practice block and will not be reset during the experiment.
	At the end of each block, participants will receive an overview of their performance (average RT, the proportion of correctly inhibited stop trials and total points earned so far) of the past block and of the previous block of the same type. Additionally, participants will receive explicit feedback messages according to their performance: (1) if the participant missed 2% or more of the go stimuli in the past block, they will be reminded to respond to the direction of the arrows and to not omit any responses; (2) if the participant missed between 2% and 7% of the go stimuli in total, they will be told that they risk the possibility that they will not receive their monetary bonus; if the participant missed 15% or more of the go stimuli in total, they will be told that they will not receive their monetary bonus after the experiment; (3) if the participant responded to 70% of the stop trials, they will be reminded to stop their response in presence of the red box; and (4) if the participant has considerably slowed down (more than a 10% increase in their average reaction time), they will be urged to stop waiting to see whether the red box will appear.

Finally, the participants will be asked to fill out a short version of the “Urgency, Premeditation (lack of), Perseverance (lack of), Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale” (sUPPS-P; Lynam, 2013; questionnaire retrieved from Cyders, Littlefield, Coffey, & Karyadi, 2014), and asked whether they felt motivated by the reward manipulation to perform better on the task. Then, the experiment will be concluded.

q9.value: We are constrained by the online platform, Prolific.co, on which will we run the experiment. The first half of the participants (50 participants) will start with a no-reward blocks (no reward – reward – no reward – reward, etc.). When these participants are tested, we can keep them from retaking the experiment and recruit the remaining half of (untested) participants, who will start with reward blocks (reward – no reward – reward – no reward, etc.).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
We have solely gathered pilot data, which will not be part of the final dataset; we have yet to collect any experimental data.

We have collected and examined the pilot data of 15 participants in order to make informed decisions about the (statistical) exclusion criteria that are to be used in the analyses of the experimental data.
 	For each participant in the pilot dataset, we have explored their progression over the trials and the overall success of the employed SSD staircases (whether they converged to 0.5 in both conditions), the rate of errors on the trials (on go trials, wrong responses and misses; on stop trials, ‘wrong responses’ (i.e., pressing the wrong key to the go stimulus) and failed inhibitions) together and separated by block type, and the reaction time distributions for each block type. Additionally, we have run BEESTS-WTF hierarchically on data of 12 participants (excluding 3 participants according to the exclusion criteria stated below) to explore the posterior distributions and rate of convergence of the group parameter estimates, as well as to visually examine individual inhibition curves.

question.value:
We will run the experiment online, using Prolific.co. We will recruit participants that have an acceptance rate equal to or exceeding 90%, are aged between 18-35, are fluent in English, use any version of Chrome or Firefox (the experiment does not support other browsers), and use a window size of (at least) 800 x 600. 
 	The recruited participants are paid an hourly base rate, which we intend to set to £6. So, given the fact that the experiment will last for approximately 45 minutes, participants are paid £4.50 for completing the experiment. Furthermore, participants will receive a monetary bonus according to their accumulated points with a maximum of £3.

q13.value: We will collect data of 100 participants, each performing five blocks of each block type, so 10 blocks in total. Each block consists of 96 trials: 72 go trials and 24 stop trials.

q14.value: We recruit 100 participants based on guidelines set by Brysbaert (2019).

question.value: We will manipulate a single variable (reward) between blocks: in reward blocks, participants will earn 10 points for successfully inhibiting their response on a stop trial; in the no reward blocks, participants will not earn any points. The total earned points will amount to a monetary reward.

We will collect: (1) demographic variables (i.e., gender and age; these will be used in the descriptive statistics); impulsivity traits as measured by the sUPPS-P (collected as a part of a larger project; untouched in the current study); (2) reaction time and accuracy on all trials (outcome measures). We will additionally be asking participants whether they felt motivated by the reward to perform better on the task.

We intend to employ the integration approach, standard BEESTS, and BEESTS-WTF to estimate parameters (see the analysis plan for more detail). 
 	In the integration approach, we estimate the go RT and subtract the average SSD to obtain the estimated SSRTs for each block type and participant. 
 	In standard BEESTS and  BEESTS-WTF, we use the reaction times on go trials, SSD, and performance on the stop trials (successful or failed inhibition) to obtain posterior samples of go parameter estimates (µ_go, σ_go, and τ_go) and stop parameter estimates (µ_stop, σ_stop, and τ_stop). In solely BEESTS-WTF, we simultaneously estimate the P_TF. Subsequently, we compute the go RT as (RT_go = µ_go+τ_go) and the SSRT as (SSRT = µ_stop+τ_stop).

We plan to (1) conduct descriptive statistics on our sample (i.e., the range, mean, and standard deviation of the age of all participants, as well as the ratio of men to women); (2) check the assumptions of the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF hierarchical models; (3) create models for each block type using (3.1) the integration approach for each participant separately, and using (3.2) standard BEESTS and (3.3) BEESTS-WTF (both BEESTS variants with 3 chains of 30000 samples each, of which 1000 burn-in; and thinning of 10) hierarchically; (4) evaluate the relative fit within block-type models of the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF by computing the Deviance Information Criteria (DICs); (5) compare between block-type models by means of (5.1) a paired t-test for the integration approach and (5.2) Bayesian p-values between the group-level parameters of the preferential BEESTS models; and (6) evaluate the absolute fit of the preferential BEESTS models by conducting posterior predictive checks. Finally, we will (7) run exploratory analyses (see the exploratory analysis section below) to check the influence of small differences in data selection related to incorrect and missed trials in the different analysis approaches.

q20.value:
For the integration approach, we will replace go misses with the maximum reaction time the participant had in that specific trial (i.e., the stimulus duration of 600 ms plus an additional blank duration ranging from 750 ms to 950 ms). 
 	For standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF, we will transform the dataset to adhere to the constraints of the software. Specifically, we plan to transform the data to five specific columns: (1) the participant ID as an integer (ranging from 0 to the sample size; “subj_idx”), (2) a Boolean indicating whether a stop signal was shown during the trial (“ss_presented”; 0 = not shown, 1 = shown), (3) a Boolean indicating whether the participant’s inhibition was successful in a given stop trial (“ss_inhibited”; 0 = failed, 1 = successful), (4) the trial’s SSD in milliseconds as an integer (“ssd”), and (5) the participant’s reaction time in milliseconds as an integer (“rt”). Additionally, we intend to remove all go misses and relabel all misses of stop trials (correct inhibitions) and ‘not-applicable’ data as ‘-999’.	
 	For the Bayesian model comparison, we will project the probability of TF 〖(P〗_TF) to a real line using a probit transformation.

q21.value: We will be using frequentist and Bayesian p-values to compare parameter estimates for the integration approach and the preferential BEESTS respectively, and Deviance Information Criteria (DICs) to compare within block-type models of standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants (1) with poor performance (i.e., 10% (or more) of all trials are go misses, go errors, and/or premature responses (i.e., responding before the onset of the go stimulus)), (2) who have many go misses for a block type in particular (i.e., a 3% go-miss differential between block types), and/or (3) exit the experiment or the full-screen mode at any time during the experiment.
	Furthermore, for the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF, we will exclude go misses (i.e., not responding on go trials) and go errors (pressing the wrong key, e.g., pressing the right arrow key in presence of a left-pointing arrow) on both go trials and stop trials (see exploratory analysis section for variants on these analyses).

q23.value: Misses on stop-signal trials (correct inhibitions) will be left as-is in the data. Misses on go trials will be removed for standard BEESTS and BEEST-WTF.

q24.value:
We will run a set of exploratory control analyses to see what the influence of slightly different data selection is for the different approaches, specifically whether go trials with incorrect or missed responses were excluded (typically done for BEESTS) or included (optimal for the integration approach, especially if the go misses are interpreted as go trials with long reaction times; Verbruggen et al., 2019). Although we expect that these trial types will be very rare and balanced across block types giving our instruction, feedback, and exclusion procedures, we want to account for the fact that the integration approach employs different data (i.e., data with go errors and transformed go misses) than the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF (i.e., data without go errors and go misses). So, we intend to run all methods again, in which we intend to (1) employ the integration approach on the data originally used in standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF and to (2) employ standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF on the data originally used in the integration approach.
	Furthermore, we plan to employ all methods again, if a considerable amount of participants exits the full-screen mode during the experiment (i.e., at least 20 participants); in these reruns, we intend to include the participants that were originally excluded for leaving the full-screen mode.

q25.value:
Reference list

Boehler, C. N., Hopf, J.-M., Stoppel, C. M., Krebs, R. M. (2012). Motivating Inhibition – Reward prospect speeds up response cancellation. Cognition, 125, 498—503. DOI: 10.1016/j.cognition.2012.07.018

Boehler, C. N., Schevernels, H., Hopf, J.-M., Stoppel, C. M., & Krebs, R. M. (2014). Reward Prospect Rapidly Speeds Up Response Inhibition via Reactive Control. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 14, 593—609

Brysbaert, M. (2019). How Many Participants Do We Have to Include in Properly Powered Experiments? A tutorial of power analysis with reference tables. Journal of Cognition, 2 (1), 1—38. DOI: 10.5334/joc.72

Cyders, M. A., Littlefield, A. K., Coffey, S., & Karyadi, K. A. (2014). Examination of a Short Version of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. Addictive Behaviors, 39 (9), 1372—1376. DOI: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2014.02.013

Gelman, A. & Rubin, D. B. (1992). Inference from Iterative Simulation using Multiple Sequences. Statistical Science, 7 (4), 457—511.

Logan, G. D. & Cowan, W. B. (1984). On the Ability to Inhibit Thought and Action: A theory of an act of control. Psychological Review, 91 (3), 295—327. DOI: 10.1037/0033-295X.91.3.295

Logan, G. D. (1994). On the ability to inhibit thought and action: A users' guide to the stop signal paradigm. In D. Dagenbach & T. H. Carr (Eds.), Inhibitory processes in attention, memory, and language (p. 189–239). Academic Press.

Lynam, D.R. (2013). Development of a short form of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. [Unpublished Technical Report]

Matzke, D., Dolan, C. V., Logan, G. D., Brown, S. D., & Wagenmakers, E.-J. (2013). Bayesian Parametric Estimation of Stop-signal Reaction Time Distributions. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 142 (4), 1047—1073. DOI: 10.1037/a0030543

Matzke, D., Love, J., & Heathcote, A. (2017). A Bayesian Approach for Estimating the Probability of Trigger Failures in the Stop-signal Paradigm. Behavioral Research, 49, 267—281. DOI: 10.3758/s13428-015-0695-8

Schevernels, H., Bombeke, K., Van der Borght, L., Hopf, J.-M., Krebs, R. M., & Boehler, C. N. (2015). Electrophysiological Evidence for the Involvement of Proactive and Reactive Control in a Rewarded Stop-signal Task. NeuroImage, 121, 115—125. DOI: 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2015.07.023

Verbruggen, F., Aron, A. R., Band, G. P. H., Beste, C., Bissett, P. G., Brockett, A. T. Brown, J. W., Chamberlain, S. R., Chambers, C. D., Colonius, H., Colzato,L. S., Corneil, B. D., Coxon, J. P., Dupuis, A., Eagle, D. M., Garavan, H., Greenhouse, I., Heathcote, A., Huster, R. J., Jahfari, S., Kenemans, J. L., Leunissen, I., Li, C.-S. R., Logan, G. D., Matzke, D., Morein-Zamir, S., Murthy, A., Paré, M., Poldrack, R. A., Ridderinkhof, K. R., Robbins, T. W., Roesch, M., Rubia, K., Schachar, R. J., Schall, J. D., Stock, A.-K., Swann, N. C., Thakkar, K. N., Van der Molen, M. W., Vermeylen, L., Vink, M., Wessel, J. R., Whelan, R., Zandbelt, B. B., & Boehler, C. N. (2019). A Consensus Guide to Capturing the Ability to Inhibit Actions and Impulsive Behaviors in the Stop-signal Task. Human Biology and Medicine (Neuroscience), 8, 1—26. DOI: 10.7554/eLife.46323

registration_responses.q1: The Effect of Rewarding Inhibition on SSRT and Trigger Failure Rate using a Block-level Reward Manipulation
registration_responses.q2: Roos Doekemeijer, C. Nico Boehler, Frederick Verbruggen
registration_responses.q3:
In accordance with Logan and Cowan’s (1984) horse race model, it is widely believed that the success of inhibiting an ongoing response depends on (1) the latency of the ongoing go process (measured as ‘go RT’), (2) the latency of the stop process (‘SSRT’), and the delay between the onsets of these two processes (‘SSD’). As the SSRT cannot be observed directly, it is typically estimated from the information at hand, e.g., by using the integration approach or Bayesian parameter estimation. Using such methods, researchers have been able to examine within- and between-individual differences in SSRT. As a specific example, research has found that rewarding correctly inhibited responses reduces SSRTs (e.g., Boehler, Hopf, Stoppel, & Krebs, 2012).	
 	Peculiarly, the vast majority of said research has operated under the assumption that the stop process occurs without fail, although the concept of ‘trigger failures’ (i.e., failures to start the stop process) has been around for over 25 years. It has been proposed that some differences attributed to differences in SSRT might actually reflect differences in the rates of trigger failures instead (Logan, 1994). To address this major concern, a recent method (BEESTS-WTF; Matzke, Love, & Heathcote, 2017) was developed that accounts for the possibility of trigger failure (P_TF) when estimating SSRTs. 
 	So far, we have employed BEESTS-WTF to reanalyze data from four of our previous studies (Boehler et al., 2012 (two separate behavioral studies); Schevernels, Krebs, Bombeke, & Boehler, 2015; Boehler, Schevernels, Hopf, Stoppel, & Krebs, 2014). In all four studies, we had used a stimulus-reward association set-up (in which the stop stimulus in a stop-signal task could be presented in one of two colors, one color was associated with reward, the other wasn’t) and obtained SSRTs via traditional non-parametric SSRT estimation (i.e., integration approach). From the initial analyses, we had concluded that rewarding inhibition led to shorter SSRTs. Yet, from the re-analyses of the data using BEESTS-WTF, we concluded that the effect of reward was driven by a decrease in trigger failure rather than by a decrease in SSRTs. Overall, there appears to be a convergence across these earlier studies that most of the difference in rewarded and non-rewarded behavior is not in the core SSRT —as has been believed previously— but in a differential rate of trigger failures. 
 	Nevertheless, these findings are limited due to the properties of the re-examined studies. Firstly, all four studies had relatively small sample sizes (ranging from 16 to 19 participants). Secondly, the general context between the studies differed considerably (i.e., the data sets originated from two behavioral studies, an EEG study, and an fMRI study), so the data sets could not be considered parts of single data set. Finally, and most importantly, all studies had used a stimulus-reward association set-up, with two different types of stop stimuli randomly intermixed within blocks. This was used to avoid any SSRT estimation problems caused by behavioral differences in the go trials. However, this particularity of the experiment could have triggered some mechanistic implementation of the reward effect (e.g., feature-based attention that enabled the superior processing of one color over that of the other) that is unlikely to play a role in other response inhibition set-ups, which ultimately confines the generalizability of our findings.
 	In the present study, we therefore aim to replicate our previous findings on the effect of reward on SSRTs and trigger failure rate in a more typical response inhibition set-up, i.e., we plan to manipulate reward across separate task blocks, use stop stimuli that are identical across reward manipulation, and simply signal reward availability by instruction. Overall, we intend to set up and employ an online, within-subjects experiment in full accordance to a recent consensus paper (Verbruggen et al., 2019), to analyze the acquired data using the integration approach, BEESTS without accounting for trigger failures (‘standard BEESTS’; Matzke, Dolan, Logan, Brown, & Wagenmakers, 2013), and BEESTS-WTF.
registration_responses.q4: Based on our findings obtained from the re-analyses of existing data sets, we expect that rewarding successful inhibition (1) decreases SSRTs according to the integration approach and standard BEESTS, (2) does not affect SSRTs, but rather reduces the rate of trigger failures according to BEESTS-WTF, compared to not rewarding successful inhibition.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: We will not get into (direct) contact with the participants, as the experiment is intended to be conducted online via Prolific.co.
registration_responses.q9: We are constrained by the online platform, Prolific.co, on which will we run the experiment. The first half of the participants (50 participants) will start with a no-reward blocks (no reward – reward – no reward – reward, etc.). When these participants are tested, we can keep them from retaking the experiment and recruit the remaining half of (untested) participants, who will start with reward blocks (reward – no reward – reward – no reward, etc.).
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11:
We have solely gathered pilot data, which will not be part of the final dataset; we have yet to collect any experimental data.

We have collected and examined the pilot data of 15 participants in order to make informed decisions about the (statistical) exclusion criteria that are to be used in the analyses of the experimental data.
 	For each participant in the pilot dataset, we have explored their progression over the trials and the overall success of the employed SSD staircases (whether they converged to 0.5 in both conditions), the rate of errors on the trials (on go trials, wrong responses and misses; on stop trials, ‘wrong responses’ (i.e., pressing the wrong key to the go stimulus) and failed inhibitions) together and separated by block type, and the reaction time distributions for each block type. Additionally, we have run BEESTS-WTF hierarchically on data of 12 participants (excluding 3 participants according to the exclusion criteria stated below) to explore the posterior distributions and rate of convergence of the group parameter estimates, as well as to visually examine individual inhibition curves.
registration_responses.q13: We will collect data of 100 participants, each performing five blocks of each block type, so 10 blocks in total. Each block consists of 96 trials: 72 go trials and 24 stop trials.
registration_responses.q14: We recruit 100 participants based on guidelines set by Brysbaert (2019).
registration_responses.q20:
For the integration approach, we will replace go misses with the maximum reaction time the participant had in that specific trial (i.e., the stimulus duration of 600 ms plus an additional blank duration ranging from 750 ms to 950 ms). 
 	For standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF, we will transform the dataset to adhere to the constraints of the software. Specifically, we plan to transform the data to five specific columns: (1) the participant ID as an integer (ranging from 0 to the sample size; “subj_idx”), (2) a Boolean indicating whether a stop signal was shown during the trial (“ss_presented”; 0 = not shown, 1 = shown), (3) a Boolean indicating whether the participant’s inhibition was successful in a given stop trial (“ss_inhibited”; 0 = failed, 1 = successful), (4) the trial’s SSD in milliseconds as an integer (“ssd”), and (5) the participant’s reaction time in milliseconds as an integer (“rt”). Additionally, we intend to remove all go misses and relabel all misses of stop trials (correct inhibitions) and ‘not-applicable’ data as ‘-999’.	
 	For the Bayesian model comparison, we will project the probability of TF 〖(P〗_TF) to a real line using a probit transformation.
registration_responses.q21: We will be using frequentist and Bayesian p-values to compare parameter estimates for the integration approach and the preferential BEESTS respectively, and Deviance Information Criteria (DICs) to compare within block-type models of standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF.
registration_responses.q22:
We will exclude participants (1) with poor performance (i.e., 10% (or more) of all trials are go misses, go errors, and/or premature responses (i.e., responding before the onset of the go stimulus)), (2) who have many go misses for a block type in particular (i.e., a 3% go-miss differential between block types), and/or (3) exit the experiment or the full-screen mode at any time during the experiment.
	Furthermore, for the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF, we will exclude go misses (i.e., not responding on go trials) and go errors (pressing the wrong key, e.g., pressing the right arrow key in presence of a left-pointing arrow) on both go trials and stop trials (see exploratory analysis section for variants on these analyses).
registration_responses.q23: Misses on stop-signal trials (correct inhibitions) will be left as-is in the data. Misses on go trials will be removed for standard BEESTS and BEEST-WTF.
registration_responses.q24:
We will run a set of exploratory control analyses to see what the influence of slightly different data selection is for the different approaches, specifically whether go trials with incorrect or missed responses were excluded (typically done for BEESTS) or included (optimal for the integration approach, especially if the go misses are interpreted as go trials with long reaction times; Verbruggen et al., 2019). Although we expect that these trial types will be very rare and balanced across block types giving our instruction, feedback, and exclusion procedures, we want to account for the fact that the integration approach employs different data (i.e., data with go errors and transformed go misses) than the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF (i.e., data without go errors and go misses). So, we intend to run all methods again, in which we intend to (1) employ the integration approach on the data originally used in standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF and to (2) employ standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF on the data originally used in the integration approach.
	Furthermore, we plan to employ all methods again, if a considerable amount of participants exits the full-screen mode during the experiment (i.e., at least 20 participants); in these reruns, we intend to include the participants that were originally excluded for leaving the full-screen mode.
registration_responses.q25:
Reference list

Boehler, C. N., Hopf, J.-M., Stoppel, C. M., Krebs, R. M. (2012). Motivating Inhibition – Reward prospect speeds up response cancellation. Cognition, 125, 498—503. DOI: 10.1016/j.cognition.2012.07.018

Boehler, C. N., Schevernels, H., Hopf, J.-M., Stoppel, C. M., & Krebs, R. M. (2014). Reward Prospect Rapidly Speeds Up Response Inhibition via Reactive Control. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 14, 593—609

Brysbaert, M. (2019). How Many Participants Do We Have to Include in Properly Powered Experiments? A tutorial of power analysis with reference tables. Journal of Cognition, 2 (1), 1—38. DOI: 10.5334/joc.72

Cyders, M. A., Littlefield, A. K., Coffey, S., & Karyadi, K. A. (2014). Examination of a Short Version of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. Addictive Behaviors, 39 (9), 1372—1376. DOI: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2014.02.013

Gelman, A. & Rubin, D. B. (1992). Inference from Iterative Simulation using Multiple Sequences. Statistical Science, 7 (4), 457—511.

Logan, G. D. & Cowan, W. B. (1984). On the Ability to Inhibit Thought and Action: A theory of an act of control. Psychological Review, 91 (3), 295—327. DOI: 10.1037/0033-295X.91.3.295

Logan, G. D. (1994). On the ability to inhibit thought and action: A users' guide to the stop signal paradigm. In D. Dagenbach & T. H. Carr (Eds.), Inhibitory processes in attention, memory, and language (p. 189–239). Academic Press.

Lynam, D.R. (2013). Development of a short form of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. [Unpublished Technical Report]

Matzke, D., Dolan, C. V., Logan, G. D., Brown, S. D., & Wagenmakers, E.-J. (2013). Bayesian Parametric Estimation of Stop-signal Reaction Time Distributions. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 142 (4), 1047—1073. DOI: 10.1037/a0030543

Matzke, D., Love, J., & Heathcote, A. (2017). A Bayesian Approach for Estimating the Probability of Trigger Failures in the Stop-signal Paradigm. Behavioral Research, 49, 267—281. DOI: 10.3758/s13428-015-0695-8

Schevernels, H., Bombeke, K., Van der Borght, L., Hopf, J.-M., Krebs, R. M., & Boehler, C. N. (2015). Electrophysiological Evidence for the Involvement of Proactive and Reactive Control in a Rewarded Stop-signal Task. NeuroImage, 121, 115—125. DOI: 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2015.07.023

Verbruggen, F., Aron, A. R., Band, G. P. H., Beste, C., Bissett, P. G., Brockett, A. T. Brown, J. W., Chamberlain, S. R., Chambers, C. D., Colonius, H., Colzato,L. S., Corneil, B. D., Coxon, J. P., Dupuis, A., Eagle, D. M., Garavan, H., Greenhouse, I., Heathcote, A., Huster, R. J., Jahfari, S., Kenemans, J. L., Leunissen, I., Li, C.-S. R., Logan, G. D., Matzke, D., Morein-Zamir, S., Murthy, A., Paré, M., Poldrack, R. A., Ridderinkhof, K. R., Robbins, T. W., Roesch, M., Rubia, K., Schachar, R. J., Schall, J. D., Stock, A.-K., Swann, N. C., Thakkar, K. N., Van der Molen, M. W., Vermeylen, L., Vink, M., Wessel, J. R., Whelan, R., Zandbelt, B. B., & Boehler, C. N. (2019). A Consensus Guide to Capturing the Ability to Inhibit Actions and Impulsive Behaviors in the Stop-signal Task. Human Biology and Medicine (Neuroscience), 8, 1—26. DOI: 10.7554/eLife.46323
registration_responses.q8.question:
We will employ a within-subjects block design with one factor, namely reward (‘reward’ blocks vs. ‘no reward’ blocks). We intend to employ five blocks of each type and will alternate them within individuals. Whether participants start with a ‘no reward’ block or a reward block will be counterbalanced.

Before the start of the experimental blocks, participants will be asked for their consent, their Prolific ID, their age and their gender. Next, participants will receive a practice block, consisting of three parts. In the first part, participants will be instructed to respond to the go stimuli (a green arrow pointing left or a green arrow pointing right) using the appropriate response keys (pressing the left arrow key to the left-pointing arrow or the right arrow key to the right-pointing arrow); 12 balanced go trials follow in random order, in which the participants will receive immediate feedback. 	
 	In the second part, participants will be instructed to stop their response in the presence of an added stop stimulus (a red box surrounding the go stimulus) presented after a variable delay and are warned that they should try to perform appropriately in both tasks without strategically slowing down their responses to the go stimuli; 40 randomized practice trials, of which 10 stop trials (balanced over go stimuli); again receiving immediate feedback.
 	In the final part, the participants will be informed that (1) in some of the upcoming blocks they can earn 10 points for successfully inhibiting their response, while not in others; (2) they will be informed about the block type at the start of each block and that symbols (‘#’ in the no reward blocks; ‘£’ in the reward blocks) will be put in a diamond shape on their screen around the area of the task-relevant stimuli as a reminder of the block type; (3) their final score will amount to a monetary bonus after the experiment, given that they performed adequately on the both the go and stop task; (4) for every 10 points, they will earn £0.05, to a maximum of 600 points (amounting to £3; explained using a table); (5) they cannot pause the experiment (lasting about 35 more minutes) beyond short fixed-duration breaks once they decide to continue.

Within each of the 10 experimental blocks, each participant is to perform 96 trials of the visual-visual Stop-Signal Task (SST), totaling to 960 trials. Each of these 960 trials starts with a 250 ms fixation point, followed by a go stimulus for 600 ms, then a blank screen for some variable duration (between 750 and 950 ms, steps of 1/60 seconds using a boxcar distribution). Note that these desired delays might differ slightly from the actual delays due to the browser’s refresh rate; to get the closest to our desired delays, we will therefore throttle the refresh rate of each participant to 60 Hz.
 	In the 72 go trials (i.e., representing 75% of the trials), the participant is to respond to the go stimulus as fast and accurately as possible, at the very latest before the start of the new trial. So, in our experiment, the participants will be able to respond during stimulus presentation but also still during the blank screen. Nevertheless, we will strongly encourage them to respond fast. 
 	In the 24 stop trials (25% of trials), a red box will appear around the go stimulus after a delay (i.e., the stop-signal delay, SSD), indicating to the participant that they should inhibit their response. If the participant is successful in inhibiting their response, they will earn 10 points in a ‘reward’ block and no points in a ‘no reward’ block, which will be converted to a monetary bonus at the end of the experiment (£0.05 for every 10 points to a maximum of 600 points, £3). Moreover, the SSD will be updated dynamically based on the participant’s success on these stop trials: if the participant is successful in inhibiting their response, the SSD will be decreased by 50 ms (to a minimum of 50 ms); if not, the SSD will be increased by 50 ms (to a maximum of 550 ms). We will employ two independent staircases, one of for each block type, and will employ an additional staircase for the practice block. The starting value of this SSD staircase in the practice block will be set to 200 ms for each participant, then the starting values of experimental staircases will be set to the final SSD of the practice block and will not be reset during the experiment.
	At the end of each block, participants will receive an overview of their performance (average RT, the proportion of correctly inhibited stop trials and total points earned so far) of the past block and of the previous block of the same type. Additionally, participants will receive explicit feedback messages according to their performance: (1) if the participant missed 2% or more of the go stimuli in the past block, they will be reminded to respond to the direction of the arrows and to not omit any responses; (2) if the participant missed between 2% and 7% of the go stimuli in total, they will be told that they risk the possibility that they will not receive their monetary bonus; if the participant missed 15% or more of the go stimuli in total, they will be told that they will not receive their monetary bonus after the experiment; (3) if the participant responded to 70% of the stop trials, they will be reminded to stop their response in presence of the red box; and (4) if the participant has considerably slowed down (more than a 10% increase in their average reaction time), they will be urged to stop waiting to see whether the red box will appear.

Finally, the participants will be asked to fill out a short version of the “Urgency, Premeditation (lack of), Perseverance (lack of), Sensation Seeking, Positive Urgency, Impulsive Behavior Scale” (sUPPS-P; Lynam, 2013; questionnaire retrieved from Cyders, Littlefield, Coffey, & Karyadi, 2014), and asked whether they felt motivated by the reward manipulation to perform better on the task. Then, the experiment will be concluded.
registration_responses.q12.question:
We will run the experiment online, using Prolific.co. We will recruit participants that have an acceptance rate equal to or exceeding 90%, are aged between 18-35, are fluent in English, use any version of Chrome or Firefox (the experiment does not support other browsers), and use a window size of (at least) 800 x 600. 
 	The recruited participants are paid an hourly base rate, which we intend to set to £6. So, given the fact that the experiment will last for approximately 45 minutes, participants are paid £4.50 for completing the experiment. Furthermore, participants will receive a monetary bonus according to their accumulated points with a maximum of £3.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate a single variable (reward) between blocks: in reward blocks, participants will earn 10 points for successfully inhibiting their response on a stop trial; in the no reward blocks, participants will not earn any points. The total earned points will amount to a monetary reward.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will collect: (1) demographic variables (i.e., gender and age; these will be used in the descriptive statistics); impulsivity traits as measured by the sUPPS-P (collected as a part of a larger project; untouched in the current study); (2) reaction time and accuracy on all trials (outcome measures). We will additionally be asking participants whether they felt motivated by the reward to perform better on the task.
registration_responses.q18.question:
We intend to employ the integration approach, standard BEESTS, and BEESTS-WTF to estimate parameters (see the analysis plan for more detail). 
 	In the integration approach, we estimate the go RT and subtract the average SSD to obtain the estimated SSRTs for each block type and participant. 
 	In standard BEESTS and  BEESTS-WTF, we use the reaction times on go trials, SSD, and performance on the stop trials (successful or failed inhibition) to obtain posterior samples of go parameter estimates (µ_go, σ_go, and τ_go) and stop parameter estimates (µ_stop, σ_stop, and τ_stop). In solely BEESTS-WTF, we simultaneously estimate the P_TF. Subsequently, we compute the go RT as (RT_go = µ_go+τ_go) and the SSRT as (SSRT = µ_stop+τ_stop).
registration_responses.q19.question: We plan to (1) conduct descriptive statistics on our sample (i.e., the range, mean, and standard deviation of the age of all participants, as well as the ratio of men to women); (2) check the assumptions of the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF hierarchical models; (3) create models for each block type using (3.1) the integration approach for each participant separately, and using (3.2) standard BEESTS and (3.3) BEESTS-WTF (both BEESTS variants with 3 chains of 30000 samples each, of which 1000 burn-in; and thinning of 10) hierarchically; (4) evaluate the relative fit within block-type models of the standard BEESTS and BEESTS-WTF by computing the Deviance Information Criteria (DICs); (5) compare between block-type models by means of (5.1) a paired t-test for the integration approach and (5.2) Bayesian p-values between the group-level parameters of the preferential BEESTS models; and (6) evaluate the absolute fit of the preferential BEESTS models by conducting posterior predictive checks. Finally, we will (7) run exploratory analyses (see the exploratory analysis section below) to check the influence of small differences in data selection related to incorrect and missed trials in the different analysis approaches.

attributes.title: Lexical competition and hemispheric specialisation
attributes.description: Here an online replication of Perea, Acha, Fraga (2008) in English speakers is pre-registered.

item1.value:
An orthographic neighbour is defined as a word that can be formed via the replacement of a single letter. The neighbourhood size (N) is the number of words that can be formed by replacing one letter of the target.

In their first experiment, Perea, Acha, and Fraga (2008) reported a facilitative effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the right visual field (left hemisphere). We aim to replicate such an effect.

item2.value:
It is important to replicate this effect for several reasons:

1) This effect provides evidence that each hemisphere has different roles in word identification and supports key predictions from the SERIOL and split-fovea models of word recognition. Replication would strengthen this evidence.
2) The original study was conducted in Spanish. We aim to further examine whether stimuli controlled in an identical manner can yield similar effects in English. 
3) The original study was conducted in the lab. We will test whether we can use online data collection methods to reliably detect hemispheric dominance in a visual half-field paradigm.

If this replication is successful, it would open up a potential new avenue for conducting visual half-field studies online. We may also be able to extend this work to test hemispheric interactions in readers with developmental dyslexia.

item3.value: We define a successful replication as showing a facilitative effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the right visual field (left hemisphere) in reaction times for word targets. The effect sizes we aim to find are smaller than those reported in Perea et al. to be conservative when conducting power analyses. We expect a right verses left visual field advantage of at least 35 ms, a main effect of neighbourhood size that is at least -15 ms, and a right verses left VF by N effect of at least -30 ms.

item6.value: The original study was conducted at the University of Santiago de Compostela in a lab.

item7.value: It was conducted in Spain at the University of Santiago de Compostela.

item8.value: Right handed, native speakers of Spanish with normal or corrected-to-normal vision.

item9.value: Stimuli were controlled by SuperLab on a PC compatible computer.

item11.value:
While the study is being run in a different language, the stimuli have been selected to be highly similar. For word targets (120 words), as in Perea et al., words were 5 letters and 2 syllables long. We used the same constraints for determining high- and low-orthographic neighbourhood size (low: 0-1 substitution neighbours; high: 7-12 substitution neighbours) while controlling for bigram frequency and frequency of occurrence.
For non-word targets (120 non-words), items were 5 letters and 2 syllables long. We used the same constraints for determining high- and low-orthographic neighbourhood size (low: 0 substitution neighbours; high: 1 substitution neighbour).

item12.value: Participants will independently complete the task online without the presence of the experimenter.

item13.value: The experimenter will not know the condition to which participants are assigned. Random allocation to the condition will be determined by Gorilla which is a platform for behavioural online research (https://gorilla.sc/).

item14.value: Experimenter will know the overall hypotheses.

item15.value: 30 native English speakers aged 1845 years-old. Participants must be right handed, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, have no significant hearing loss, history of neurological disease, head injury, epilepsy or diagnosis of language and/or reading impairments.

item16.value: Extensive piloting was conducted for this task. Based on pilot data, power calculations for a linear mixed-effects model fit to target word reaction times (RTs) indicated that a sample of 30 participants would be sufficient to detect the meaningful fixed effects of interest comparing left and right visual fields and the main effect of orthographic neighbourhood (VF by ortho-N interaction) for left and right visual fields with at least 80% power. For further details see ‘pilot_dat_and_power.Rmd’ on the OSF: https://osf.io/vknbp/.

item24.value:
Perea et al. conducted their original experiment with Spanish native speakers and our replication will use native English speakers. As a result, the effect may be influenced by the orthographic depth of the language. In Spanish, the magnitude of the facilitative effect of orthographic neighbourhood size tends to be smaller than in English.  Therefore, we may observe larger effects of orthographic neighbourhoods in our replication study.

The effect size may also be influenced by the location of the study. Under lab conditions, Perea et al. will have maintained consistency of the environment in which participants completed the experiment. We will not have such control. As such, there may be more variability in the data which may lead to differences in the observed effect size.


The effect size may also be influenced by the location od the study. Under lab conditions, Perea et al. will have maintained consistency of the environment in which participants completed the experiment. We will not have such control. As such, there may be more variability in the data which may lead to differences in the observed effect size.

item25.value: We ran numerous small scale pilot studies to ensure that we could observe a numerical right visual field (relative to the left visual field) advantage in both RT and accuracy. This indicated that there was an advantage when completing this study online.

item26.value:
While we cannot observe adherence to the task (as participants complete the task online), we can apply extra criteria beyond Perea et al. that can help us identify participants who do not adhere to the task. 

1) First, we will remove participants who score below chance (less than 50% accuracy) in any visual field (right, left, and central). 
2) For reaction times analysis, we will consider only accurate reaction times that are longer than 250 ms and shorter than 1200 ms.
2) Due to potential issues with buffering and poor internet connections when completing the task, we will use the criteria outlined by Hoaglin-Iglewicz to exclude outliers in the data for reaction time for each individual subject after removing reaction times less than 250 ms and longer than 1200 ms. Our cut-off criterion will be set to 1.65 instead of the typical 2.2. This is because we expect to obtain asymmetric distributions for reaction time, since reaction time is always non-negative, and so most outliers will be in one tail of the distribution. 

To ensure that our participants are all right-handed to the same degree as Perea et al., we will remove and replace participants who score less than 80 of the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield, 1971).

item27.value:
We will fit identical statistical models to:

1) word target errors
2) log-transformed word target reaction times

Rather than fit F1 (subjects) and F2 (items) ANOVAs to the data, we will use (generalized) linear mixed-effects models. This reduces the risk of inflated error by reducing the number of statistical models being fit to the data. 

For word target errors, generalised linear mixed-effects models will be fit to binomial data and will use the logit function. For reaction times, linear mixed-effects models will be fit to log-transformed reaction times. 

The model for both error and log-reaction times will adopt an identical structure:

dv~ VF + condition + VF:condition + (1 | participant) + (1 | item). 

Visual field (VF) will have three levels: Left VF, right VF, and central VF. 
Condition will have two levels: high- and low-orthographic neighbour substitutions. 

For condition, the contr.sum function will be used to implement summed contrasts. This will enable the main effect of orthographic neighbourhood to be examined. 
For VF, the contr.helmert function will be used to implement helmert contrasts. This will enable us to contrast the mean for right and left VF directly, and then contrasts the mean of the right and left VFs with the mean for the central VF. 
This series of contrasts will result in the intercept corresponding to the grand mean.

Perea et al. included a main effect of counterbalance list in their experiment. When analysing pilot data we did not observe any increase in model fit when including a fixed effect coding for list. As such, we do not intend to include this in our planned analysis.

item28.value:
1) observing faster reaction times and reduced errors in the central visual field relative to the mean of the left and right visual fields.
2) observing faster reaction times and reduced errors in the right visual field relative to the left visual field.
3) a facilitative effect of orthographic neighbourhood in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of orthographic neighbourhood in the right visual field (left hemisphere) in reaction times for word targets. 

While we plan on analysing error rate, it may not be sensitive enough to capture the effects of orthographic N. Thus, it is not part of our criteria for successful replication.

registration_responses.item1:
An orthographic neighbour is defined as a word that can be formed via the replacement of a single letter. The neighbourhood size (N) is the number of words that can be formed by replacing one letter of the target.

In their first experiment, Perea, Acha, and Fraga (2008) reported a facilitative effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the right visual field (left hemisphere). We aim to replicate such an effect.
registration_responses.item2:
It is important to replicate this effect for several reasons:

1) This effect provides evidence that each hemisphere has different roles in word identification and supports key predictions from the SERIOL and split-fovea models of word recognition. Replication would strengthen this evidence.
2) The original study was conducted in Spanish. We aim to further examine whether stimuli controlled in an identical manner can yield similar effects in English. 
3) The original study was conducted in the lab. We will test whether we can use online data collection methods to reliably detect hemispheric dominance in a visual half-field paradigm.

If this replication is successful, it would open up a potential new avenue for conducting visual half-field studies online. We may also be able to extend this work to test hemispheric interactions in readers with developmental dyslexia.
registration_responses.item3: We define a successful replication as showing a facilitative effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of a word's neighbourhood size in the right visual field (left hemisphere) in reaction times for word targets. The effect sizes we aim to find are smaller than those reported in Perea et al. to be conservative when conducting power analyses. We expect a right verses left visual field advantage of at least 35 ms, a main effect of neighbourhood size that is at least -15 ms, and a right verses left VF by N effect of at least -30 ms.
registration_responses.item6: The original study was conducted at the University of Santiago de Compostela in a lab.
registration_responses.item7: It was conducted in Spain at the University of Santiago de Compostela.
registration_responses.item8: Right handed, native speakers of Spanish with normal or corrected-to-normal vision.
registration_responses.item9: Stimuli were controlled by SuperLab on a PC compatible computer.
registration_responses.item11:
While the study is being run in a different language, the stimuli have been selected to be highly similar. For word targets (120 words), as in Perea et al., words were 5 letters and 2 syllables long. We used the same constraints for determining high- and low-orthographic neighbourhood size (low: 0-1 substitution neighbours; high: 7-12 substitution neighbours) while controlling for bigram frequency and frequency of occurrence.
For non-word targets (120 non-words), items were 5 letters and 2 syllables long. We used the same constraints for determining high- and low-orthographic neighbourhood size (low: 0 substitution neighbours; high: 1 substitution neighbour).
registration_responses.item12: Participants will independently complete the task online without the presence of the experimenter.
registration_responses.item13: The experimenter will not know the condition to which participants are assigned. Random allocation to the condition will be determined by Gorilla which is a platform for behavioural online research (https://gorilla.sc/).
registration_responses.item14: Experimenter will know the overall hypotheses.
registration_responses.item15: 30 native English speakers aged 1845 years-old. Participants must be right handed, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, have no significant hearing loss, history of neurological disease, head injury, epilepsy or diagnosis of language and/or reading impairments.
registration_responses.item16: Extensive piloting was conducted for this task. Based on pilot data, power calculations for a linear mixed-effects model fit to target word reaction times (RTs) indicated that a sample of 30 participants would be sufficient to detect the meaningful fixed effects of interest comparing left and right visual fields and the main effect of orthographic neighbourhood (VF by ortho-N interaction) for left and right visual fields with at least 80% power. For further details see ‘pilot_dat_and_power.Rmd’ on the OSF: https://osf.io/vknbp/.
registration_responses.item24:
Perea et al. conducted their original experiment with Spanish native speakers and our replication will use native English speakers. As a result, the effect may be influenced by the orthographic depth of the language. In Spanish, the magnitude of the facilitative effect of orthographic neighbourhood size tends to be smaller than in English.  Therefore, we may observe larger effects of orthographic neighbourhoods in our replication study.

The effect size may also be influenced by the location of the study. Under lab conditions, Perea et al. will have maintained consistency of the environment in which participants completed the experiment. We will not have such control. As such, there may be more variability in the data which may lead to differences in the observed effect size.


The effect size may also be influenced by the location od the study. Under lab conditions, Perea et al. will have maintained consistency of the environment in which participants completed the experiment. We will not have such control. As such, there may be more variability in the data which may lead to differences in the observed effect size.
registration_responses.item25: We ran numerous small scale pilot studies to ensure that we could observe a numerical right visual field (relative to the left visual field) advantage in both RT and accuracy. This indicated that there was an advantage when completing this study online.
registration_responses.item26:
While we cannot observe adherence to the task (as participants complete the task online), we can apply extra criteria beyond Perea et al. that can help us identify participants who do not adhere to the task. 

1) First, we will remove participants who score below chance (less than 50% accuracy) in any visual field (right, left, and central). 
2) For reaction times analysis, we will consider only accurate reaction times that are longer than 250 ms and shorter than 1200 ms.
2) Due to potential issues with buffering and poor internet connections when completing the task, we will use the criteria outlined by Hoaglin-Iglewicz to exclude outliers in the data for reaction time for each individual subject after removing reaction times less than 250 ms and longer than 1200 ms. Our cut-off criterion will be set to 1.65 instead of the typical 2.2. This is because we expect to obtain asymmetric distributions for reaction time, since reaction time is always non-negative, and so most outliers will be in one tail of the distribution. 

To ensure that our participants are all right-handed to the same degree as Perea et al., we will remove and replace participants who score less than 80 of the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield, 1971).
registration_responses.item27:
We will fit identical statistical models to:

1) word target errors
2) log-transformed word target reaction times

Rather than fit F1 (subjects) and F2 (items) ANOVAs to the data, we will use (generalized) linear mixed-effects models. This reduces the risk of inflated error by reducing the number of statistical models being fit to the data. 

For word target errors, generalised linear mixed-effects models will be fit to binomial data and will use the logit function. For reaction times, linear mixed-effects models will be fit to log-transformed reaction times. 

The model for both error and log-reaction times will adopt an identical structure:

dv~ VF + condition + VF:condition + (1 | participant) + (1 | item). 

Visual field (VF) will have three levels: Left VF, right VF, and central VF. 
Condition will have two levels: high- and low-orthographic neighbour substitutions. 

For condition, the contr.sum function will be used to implement summed contrasts. This will enable the main effect of orthographic neighbourhood to be examined. 
For VF, the contr.helmert function will be used to implement helmert contrasts. This will enable us to contrast the mean for right and left VF directly, and then contrasts the mean of the right and left VFs with the mean for the central VF. 
This series of contrasts will result in the intercept corresponding to the grand mean.

Perea et al. included a main effect of counterbalance list in their experiment. When analysing pilot data we did not observe any increase in model fit when including a fixed effect coding for list. As such, we do not intend to include this in our planned analysis.
registration_responses.item28:
1) observing faster reaction times and reduced errors in the central visual field relative to the mean of the left and right visual fields.
2) observing faster reaction times and reduced errors in the right visual field relative to the left visual field.
3) a facilitative effect of orthographic neighbourhood in the left visual field (i.e., right hemisphere) and an inhibitory effect of orthographic neighbourhood in the right visual field (left hemisphere) in reaction times for word targets. 

While we plan on analysing error rate, it may not be sensitive enough to capture the effects of orthographic N. Thus, it is not part of our criteria for successful replication.
